2654615159.resolved_title: India’s Untouchable Queen of the Dead
2654615159.excerpt: Legions of the sick and elderly go to great lengths to die in India’s holiest city. One mysterious woman guards this fiery entrance to eternal bliss.

1.caption:
Bachhan Chowdhury, 55, after his 
shift at the burning ghat. He calls his job “dead bodies management” 
with an ironic connotation. He has five children and already knows the 
males will work here one day.

2.caption:
Saranga Devi sits by the sacred fire
 on the ghat. It is unusual, perhaps unprecedented, for a woman to be 
the chief of the burning ghat. She inherited the role from her deceased 
husband, Dom Raja.

3.caption: The main burning ground in Varanasi, the Manikarnika ghat, seen from above. There are different levels of terraces and gated grounds where the dead are burned according to their caste: the lower the caste, the lower the ground.

4.caption: An Aghori Baba meditating inside a soot-blackened and abandoned building behind Manikarnika ghat. Aghoris are one of the most extreme and controversial sect of Hindu holy men, called sadhus, who often dwell near cremation grounds.

5.caption:
Chotu Chowdhury, 65, has been a Dom 
for 40 years. He used to have a sweets shop, too, but the business 
wasn’t good enough. “Nobody will buy from a Dom’s shop,” he says with a 
resigned look. So he turned back to the burning ghat.

6.caption: Male relatives of the deceased carry a stretcher towards the Ganges River as part of the ritual before cremation. These waters are believed to be holy, purifying and miraculous.

7.caption: Pots used to collect water from the Ganges to purify the body. The dead are considered impure in Hinduism, hence the need of someone to take care of the dead during the cremation rituals, including being cleansed.

8.caption: A corpse is wrapped in colorful cloth before being dipped in the river. On the river, boats loaded with wood cruise towards Manikarnika to unload their wood in the early morning. Manikarnika is the place where every Hindu wishes to be cremated.

10.caption: A man walks on the piles of wood stocked in the back streets behind the Manikarnika ghat. The wood trade is very lucrative and the price spans from 3,000 to 50,000 rupees

11.caption: An iron scale on the banks of the Ganges, used by Doms to weigh the wood. The quantity of wood is calculated by the weight of the deceased. The cost will be bargained by the relatives according to quality and quantity needed.

12.caption: An iron scale on the banks of the Ganges, used by Doms to weigh the wood. The quantity of wood is calculated by the weight of the deceased. The cost will be bargained by the relatives according to quality and quantity needed.

13.caption: Shiva Chowdhury, 37, started this job when he was 17, as his father did before him. He can count up to seven generations in his family who all worked on the burning grounds. “Many drink or smoke drugs,” Chowdhury says. “It’s so horrible to be in touch with death all day; I can’t stand my job.”

1.caption: Winning isn't easy, but it should at least be possible. All illustrations by Kristen Boydstun.

2.caption: Milk bottles made of iron were much harder to knock over.

3.caption: Carnival amusements were once considered a threat to the soul of rural America.

2632748612.resolved_title: The Shipwrecked Sailors & the Wandering Cod
2632748612.excerpt: In the remote archipelago of Lofoten, Arctic cod have been dried on oceanfront racks since the age of the Vikings. This is the unlikely story of how the humble fish became king of Norway.

2.caption:
The dried bodies of skrei, or "wandering" cod, which fill
		the Norwegian Sea from February to April. Once caught, they're flayed 
		and hung to dry to make Norway's treasured stockfish.

3.caption:
Left: Dozens of cod heads are strung up in bunches to dry on racks
		near the ocean. Most of these are exported to Nigeria, while many of 
		the bodies, once dried, go to Italy. Right: Steinar Larsen, the owner 
		of the Lofoten Stockfish Museum in Å, near the southern tip of the archipelago.

4.caption:
For their series Ghetto Spedalsk, Norwegian street artists Pøbel 
		and Dolk placed pieces on abandoned buildings throughout Lofoten, 
		including this one reading “in cod we trust.”

6.caption: The Lofoten islands.

7.caption:
Left: Created by collector Venke Hoff, Kaviar Factory
		is an international contemporary art gallery built in an old 
		cod-roe-processing plant on Henningsvær's coast. The sign is original. Right: Lighthouse tattoo and Lofoten's hallowed stockfish: Chef Johan 
		Petrini has devoted himself to the region's rhythms and tastes.

8.caption: Notes on cod.

9.caption:
Fiskesuppe, as it's called in Norwegian, can be found at 
		nearly every restaurant on the Lofoten Islands of northern Norway. Local
		cooks sometimes swap out cod for other seasonal fish, such as salmon, 
		or add accents like red pepper, chunks of bacon, or chive oil.

3644443407.resolved_title: And Then the Sea Glowed a Magnificent Milky Green
3644443407.excerpt: A chance encounter with a rare phenomenon called a milky sea connects a sailor and a scientist to explain the ocean’s ghostly glow. This article is also available in audio format. Listen now, download, or subscribe to “Hakai Magazine Audio Edition” through your favorite podcast app.

1.caption: Illustration by Mercedes Minck

2.caption: In August 2010, author Sam Keck Scott and his crewmates were sailing in the Arabian Sea when they became some of the few people to witness a milky sea. Photo courtesy of Biosphere Foundation

3.caption: There are no existing photos of a milky sea in nature, but this sample of bioluminescing bacteria demonstrates the uniform glow of the phenomenon on a small scale. Photo courtesy of Steve Miller

4.caption: Steve Miller, director of the Cooperative Institute for Research in the Atmosphere, and his colleagues have identified the location of several milky seas by using satellite images acquired with the use of specialized day/night band instruments that can perceive bioluminescence from space. Photo courtesy of Steve Miller

3941052196.excerpt: Rats are less pestilent and more lovable than we think. Can we learn to live with them? This article is also available in audio format. Listen now, download, or subscribe to “Hakai Magazine Audio Edition” through your favorite podcast app.

1.caption: Illustration by Sarah Gilman

1919621332.excerpt: In the 20th century, Japanese anthropologists and officials tried to hide the existence of the Indigenous Ainu. Then the Ainu fought back like their cousins, the bears. This article is also available in audio format.

1.caption: The Ainu, the Indigenous people of Japan, have fought Japanese domination for centuries. As this century unfolds, their efforts are finally paying off. Photo by Chris Willson/Alamy Stock Photo

2.caption: A bear’s head carved from sea mammal bone was found by a volunteer on the first day of the three-week dig at Hamanaka II in 2016. Photo by Tyler Cantwell/Andrzej Weber/University of Alberta

3.caption: Cally Steussy and Meriah Dainard clean animal bones recovered at the Hamanaka II site with toothbrushes in a school gym. Photo by Jude Isabella

4.caption: Illustration by Mark Garrison

5.caption: Hamanaka II on Rebun Island is full of animal remains—sea mammals, deer, dogs, and pigs—some dating back 3,000 years before present. Bones preserve well in the island’s sandy soil. Bone preservation in the acidic soils of neighboring Hokkaido, a large volcanic island, is rare. Photo by Jude Isabella

6.caption: Illustration by Mark Garrison

7.caption: The Ainu fished salmon and trout on rivers using gaff-like spears. They headed to sea in large, sophisticated canoes for tuna, swordfish, sunfish, and marine mammals—fur seals, sea lions, and whales. Photo by The Protected Art Archive/Alamy Stock Photo

8.caption: Hirofumi Kato, an archaeologist with Hokkaido University’s Center for Ainu and Indigenous Studies in Sapporo, began the Hamanaka II dig in 2011. Photo by Jude Isabella

9.caption: On Rebun Island, off the coast of Hokkaido, Hirofumi Kato, left, Zoe Eddy, foreground, and volunteers pile sandbags on the Hamanaka II archaeological site, where they will stay until the dig continues the following year. Photo by Jude Isabella

10.caption: This photo was taken sometime in the 1880s and shows a group of Ainu people at their village in Hokkaido. Photo by Chronicle/Alamy Stock Photo

11.caption: Taken in 1955, this photo shows an Ainu woman feeding a bear cub. The Ainu raised bear cubs as they would a member of the family, until the iyomante, the bear-sending ceremony. Photo by Evans/Three Lions/Getty Images

12.caption: This 1901 illustration shows an Ainu iyomante. The iyomante fascinated Japanese and Europeans alike. Photo by Ivy Close Images/Alamy Stock Photo

13.caption: Tomoe Yahata and Mai Ishihara, who both have Ainu heritage, meet for the first time at the Ainu Museum in Shiraoi. Photo by Jude Isabella

14.caption: Ainu elders perform a ceremony at Hamanaka II. The archaeological dig initiated by Hirofumi Kato is the first to consult, involve, or ask permission of the Ainu. Photo by Mayumi Okada

15.caption: Born in Biratori in 1952, Ainu Shigeru Kayano began collecting his people’s artifacts and recording their folk tales. He opened the Nibutani Ainu Cultural Museum in 1972, a private collection of items he collected over two decades. He was the first Ainu member of Japan’s parliament in 1994, the same year his memoir, Our Land Was a Forest, was published. Photo by Kyodo News/Getty Images

16.caption: Anutari Ainu, which translates to we humans, launched in June 1973. Out of a small Sapporo apartment, a collective of mostly women produced an influential Ainu voice in Japan’s civil rights movement.

17.caption: Around the age of 12 or 13, Ainu young women began tattooing their lips, hands, and arms. By age 15 or 16, the tattoos were finished, and the young women ready for marriage. Young men were also considered adults at 15 or 16. Photo by Hulton-Deutsch Collection/Corbis/Getty Images

3668334197.resolved_title: Romance, Politics, and Ecological Damage: The Saga of Sable Island’s Wild Horses
3668334197.excerpt: They’ve roamed free for hundreds of years, but is that freedom harming the ecosystem they call home? This article is also available in audio format. Listen now, download, or subscribe to “Hakai Magazine Audio Edition” through your favorite podcast app.

1.caption: Horses were first left on Sable Island, Nova Scotia, in the 1700s, and their descendants have roamed free ever since. These wild horses have behaved as invasive species have the world over—altering the natural ecosystem. But unlike other introduced species, such as rats, starlings, or zebra mussels, they’ve been deemed as “naturalized” and are treated more as wildlife than the feral animals they are. Photo by Julie Marshall/Shutterstock

2.caption: Sable Island is a 40-kilometer-long sandbar 161 kilometers off the coast of Nova Scotia. Map data by ArcGIS

3.caption: The horses of Sable Island share their home with the world’s largest breeding colony of gray seals. Photo courtesy of Parks Canada

4.caption: It is unclear how many horses were first landed at Sable Island in the 1700s, but today’s population is somewhere between 500 and 600. Photo courtesy of Parks Canada

5.caption: The charisma of Sable Island’s very photogenic wild horses has furthered their existence on the island. When the Canadian government decided to remove the horses in the 1960s over concerns of animal welfare and the ecological damage the horses might be doing, public outcry reversed the decision. Photo courtesy of Parks Canada

6.caption: Parks Canada’s Fences in the Sand study is using exclosures to observe what happens to the natural ecosystem when horses are excluded. Photo courtesy of Parks Canada

7.caption: If horses didn’t live on Sable Island, would people care much about this small spit of shifting sand? Photo courtesy of Parks Canada

3353149648.resolved_title: How to Save an Ancient Language Before It Disappears Forever
3353149648.excerpt: It’s 6:30 p.m. at a radio studio in Miaoli, a small city in Western Taiwan. Yin Chang is plugged in. Her headphones are on, and the microphone is adjusted close to her mouth. The lights are dim; a blue banner declaring “Voice of Hakka Radio 97.1 FM” hangs behind her.

2.credit: Photo courtesy of DJ Yin Chang
2.caption: At the 97.1 FM Hakka radio station, DJ Yin Chang runs “Henai,” an evening Hakka language program, and “Multivitamin,” a night Mandarin language program aimed at youth. As a DJ, Chang works to promote the Hakka language, Hakka music and rising Hakka musicians.

3.caption: A restaurant in Guanyin, located in Taoyuan County, serves traditional Hakka cuisine. At the front is bantiao, a type of rice noodle soup. At the back are pork strips, salted chicken and soy-braised seaweed, tofu and eggs. These dishes can be eaten with tangy orange sauce, which is in a small dish on the table.

4.caption: A Hakka lantern hangs near a bus stop in Hsinpu, a small city in Hsinchu County with a large concentration of Hakka people. The lantern is made of traditional Hakka floral fabric.

5.caption: Hakka artists weave a basket in the traditional Hakka style. However, to modernize the craft, they use plastic strips rather than wood splints.

6.caption: The College of Hakka Studies at National Chiao Tung University is located in Hsinchu in northwestern Taiwan. With 69.5 percent of the population being Hakka, Hsinchu is the county with the highest concentration of Hakka people in Taiwan.

7.caption: Baiwei Lin, 23, poses in front of her desk at the College of Hakka Studies at National Central University. Inspired by her Hakka identity, Lin is a graduate student in the program. She is currently focusing her research on Meinung, an area in southern Taiwan with a large concentration of Hakka people.

8.caption: Henzung Zhang, 90, flips through the pages of a Hakka dictionary he worked on for ten years. The dictionary is currently used by Hakka language teachers and at Hakka cultural centers. He wrote the dictionary in hopes of teaching Hakka to younger generations more accurately, as primary schools are now required to teach mother languages, including Hakka.

9.caption: Zhang and his grandson visit a Hakka quadrangle of a family friend and sit at the center shrine. Hakka quadrangles are similar to Beijing’s quadrangles or courtyard houses. However, Hakka quadrangles are enclosed by buildings on three sides rather than four. The center room is a shrine for venerating ancestors.

1.caption: In the Middle Ages, communal sleeping was entirely normal – travellers who had just met would share the same bed, as would masters and their servants

1.caption: The Tahiti, seen here sailing on San Francisco Bay, was a 124-foot brigantine built by Turner Shipyards in 1881. Courtesy Hunt Family.

2.caption: This painting of Matthew Turner in his later years is still in the collection of Turner’s descendants. Courtesy Hunt Family.

3.caption: Alan Olson aboard the Matthew Turner, which will begin educational sailing trips this fall from its home base in Sausalito, California.

4.caption: Matthew Turner

5.caption: From 1852 to 1853, Matthew Turner and Richard Rundle were partners in this gold mine at Big Oak Flat, California. Courtesy Hunt Family.

6.caption: In 1853, Turner parlayed the money he’d made as a gold prospector into this ship, the Toranto, which he used to haul lumber from Mendocino County to San Francisco. Courtesy Hunt Family.

7.caption: Matthew Turner at age 28, shortly after retiring from the life of a gold prospector. Courtesy Hunt Family.

8.caption: The Matthew Turner

9.caption: A TV show in the late 1950s called “Bold Journey” was the spark that ignited Alan Olson’s interest in sailing.

10.caption: San Francisco harbor in the 1880s. Courtesy Hunt Family.

11.caption: The Turner-Chapman building

12.caption: The point of land above the words “Brick Yard” just below Mission Bay was probably the site of Matthew Turner’s first shipyard before he moved it to Benicia.

13.caption: Matthew Turner rented a room at 711 Tennessee Street in San Francisco from his former gold-mining partner Richard Rundle. When Rundle died, Turner married his widow, Ashbeline, and assumed responsibility for the couple’s three young children. This photo of the Turner family is circa 1880s. Courtesy Hunt Family.

14.caption: Before he passed in 2014, Matthew Turner family historian Murray Chapman Hunt

15.caption: Sisters Eileen Hunt

16.caption: The trim of the Matthew Turner’s 11 sails is controlled by almost 100 lines. At right is the bank of batteries that will store energy generated as the ship’s propellers turn in the water while under sail. Courtesy Call of the Sea.

17.caption: A view up into the rigging of the Matthew Turner being built by Call of the Sea.

19.caption: Little Eva at age 5 in 1894 and age 84 in 1973. She lived to be 97. Courtesy Hunt Family.

20.caption: The new Matthew Turner being built by Call of the Sea takes much of its design from another Turner Shipyards brigantine, the Galilee, seen here in 1907 near Sitka, Alaska. Courtesy Hunt Family.

2304480303.given_title: It Came From the ’70s: The Story of Your Grandma’s Weird Couch
2304480303.resolved_title: The Story of Your Grandma’s Weird Couch
2304480303.excerpt: Futzing around on social media, as one does, I recently stumbled upon a meme that hit close to home. Over a picture-patterned sofa in an autumnal-colored velour with scrolling dark wood trim, it declared, “Everyone’s grandparents had this couch. Everyone’s.

2.caption: Top: This sofa’s shape, structure, and colors are almost identical to my grandmother’s couch.

3.caption: A 1958 still from the TV series “Gunsmoke” shows Amanda Blake as Miss Kitty and Milburn Stone as Doc Adams.

4.caption: A found snapshot from 1977 shows a grandpa hanging out with his grandkids on a brown-tone floral Colonial-style wingback sofa.

5.caption: Depending on the meme, everyone—or everyone’s grandma—had this sofa. Here, the busy pattern on the synthetic velour includes an old-timey clock. At least, I think that’s what’s happening.

6.caption: The “floral sofa” in this Sears Open Hearth Country Home ad, which appeared in the May 1977 issue of “Redbook,” is the closest advertising image I’ve found to the Grandma Couch.

7.caption: An early ’70s kitchen in Arizona with a patriotic eagle, Knotty Pine cabinets, modified Windsor chairs, and a Harvest Gold and Burnt Orange color palette.

8.caption: On the right side of this 1970 image of a Montgomery Ward floor, you can see a brown floral couch similar to my grandma’s, as well as a Colonial Revival coffee table that resembles hers, but with different hardware. In the background is an orange plaid couch.

9.caption: This 1970s catalog page shows Spanish or Mediterranean style furniture, heavy with carved wood gewgaws.

10.caption: In this 1970s ad, a stylish young woman holds a book on a floral Grandma Couch while an unseen companion pets her golden retriever, who rests on shag carpeting surrounded by Colonial Revival furniture.

11.caption: The Spring/Summer 1976 Sears catalog shows a family touring the home of Founding Father John Adams in Quincy, Massachusetts.

12.caption: Another 1977 ad for the Sears Open Hearth Country Home furniture line. Tartan plaid made of indestructible synthetic weaves, Windsor chairs, red tile, braided rugs, and patriotic colors were all a part of the “Spirit of ’76” Colonial Revival.

13.credit: Photo by Julius Shulman, © J. Paul Getty Trust. Getty Research Institute, Los Angeles
13.caption: The iconic Case Study House No. 22 was designed by architect Pierre Koenig for Clarence “Buck” Stahl and built in the Hollywood Hills in 1959.

14.caption: An article in the September 1958 edition of “Family Circle” extols the virtues of affordable Colonial Revival and Early American furniture.

15.caption: Game birds roost among wildflowers on this fake-velour ’70s Grandma Couch.

16.caption: A young dad cuddles with his baby on a Colonial Revival sofa with a brown Herculon plaid fabric in this 1979 vernacular photo.

17.caption: Pam Kueber’s favorite “Bicentennial Chic” room from a mid-1970s Ethan Allen catalog.

18.caption: This 1952 ad for Formica countertops shows the modern material paired with Knotty Pine cabinets and paneling. The ad text promotes “the warmth and charm of the early American kitchen.”

19.caption: Christine’s Creations in Woodstock, Georgia, upcycled this grandma furniture set into stylish outdoor furniture. But who’s to say how long apple green and apple red will be en vogue?

20.caption: A Grandma Couch meme shared by comedian, actor, and rapper Mike Epps on Facebook.

1.caption: Located in Watts, Los Angeles, the Watts Towers were built by Sabato Rodia over a period of three decades using concrete, teapots, plastic toys, seashells, and more. Photo by Mauritius Images GmbH/Alamy Stock Photo

2.caption: Sabato Rodia was an Italian immigrant who arrived in the United States to work as a coal miner and construction worker. He started building the Watts Towers in Los Angeles in his spare time soon after purchasing a triangular piece of land in the 1920s. Photo by Hulton Archive/Getty Images

3.caption: A biologist at Leiden University in the Netherlands was analyzing shells collected by a Dutch paleontologist in the 1890s when she realized there were distinct zigzag patterns etched by Homo erectus, making them the oldest intentional engravings in the world. Photo by Wim Lustenhouwer/VU University Amsterdam, Naturalis Biodiversity Center, Joordens et al 2015

4.caption: In some cultures, seashells are used as tokens placed in or around graves. For instance, this Christian cemetery is located on a Senegalese island composed of shell mounds. Photo by Ariadne Van Zandbergen/Alamy Stock Photo

5.caption: Tiger cowries have been popular in various cultures, including those in Japan, India, and West Africa. These mollusks were used as modes of communicating messages between villages, as decorations, or associated with religious rituals and deities. Photo by Panther Media GmbH/Alamy Stock Photo

6.caption: In Spain, scallop shell signs mark the way on the Camino de Santiago, a path taken by pilgrims visiting the tomb of James the Greater. Photo by Room the Agency/Alamy Stock Photo

7.caption: The Watts Towers consist of 17 interconnected structures that Sabato Rodia neither used any specialized tools for nor had a design for when he started. Photo by Mauritius Images GmbH/Alamy Stock Photo

8.caption: Human beings have been fascinated with seashells since forever. We have used them for trade, as canvasses for engravings, and symbols of procreation and wealth. Photo by ElenaR/Shutterstock

536179782.resolved_title: Into the Cave of Chile’s Witches
536179782.excerpt: Did members of a powerful society of warlocks actually murder their enemies and kidnap children? There is a place in South America that was once the end of the earth.

1.caption: A photo sometimes said to depict members of Chiloé’s murderous society of warlocks—founded, so they claimed, in 1786 and destroyed by the great trial of 1880-81.

2.caption: The great British traveler Bruce Chatwin wrote a memorable description of Chiloé’s sorcerers. But how rooted in reality is it?

3.caption: Chiloé, Chile’s second-largest island, is about the size of Puerto Rico and full of legends—many of them concerning La Recta Provincia.

4.caption: Quicavi, a small village on Chiloé’s sheltered east coast, was one of the two main bases of the island’s warlocks. A huge cave hidden just outside the settlement was home to their central council.

5.caption: The Chilean historian Benjamín Vicuña McKenna

6.caption: Francisco Goya’s paintings of witches did much to shape perceptions of sorcery in Spanish-speaking societies in the late 18th and early 19th centuries.

7.caption: The Traiguén River in 1915. It was here that initiates of Chiloé’s sect of witches were said to wash off the effects of the Christian baptism, bathing in the freezing waters for 15 successive nights. During this ordeal, the writer Bruce Chatwin notes, “they were allowed a little toast.”

8.caption: The waters surrounding Chiloé are cold and often hazardous to navigate—and the extreme tidal range recorded there might explain the outcome of a legendary battle between a Spanish wizard and a local witch, held in 1786, which supposedly gave birth to the society known as the Righteous Province.

9.caption: Mapuche machis—healers and shamans—photographed in 1903

10.caption: Luis Rodriguez Martiniano, who in 1880 put in motion the investigation that led to the great witch trial.

11.caption: Houses in Chiloé. On a coast where tides rise and fall by up to 20 feet, the use of stilts is a common characteristic of seafront buildings.

3264231642.resolved_title: The Once-Classified Tale of Juanita Moody
3264231642.excerpt: On the morning of Sunday, October 14, 1962, Juanita Moody exited the headquarters of the National Security Agency, at Fort Meade, Maryland, and walked the short distance to her car, parked in one of the front-row spaces reserved for top leadership.

1.caption:
Moody, seen in 1943, was an undergraduate at Western Carolina Teacher's College when she volunteered for  the Army and became a wunderkind code breaker at the Signal Intelligence Service, forerunner of the NSA.
    
    
      Susan Seubert

2.caption:
The National Security Agency was established on October 24, 1952, in a secret memo signed by President Harry Truman. Moody was there from Day 1.
    
    
      NSA

3.caption:
Moody was instrumental in the NSA’s use of new technology
to process critical intelligence. Below, IBM machines at the agency.
    
    
      NSA

4.credit: Raul Corrales, The Canadian Press / AP Images
4.caption:
Fidel Castro observes the battle at the Bay of Pigs in April 1961 as the invasion was underway. The attack led Castro to eventually allow Soviet nuclear missiles in Cuba.
    
    
      Raul Corrales, The Canadian Press / AP Images

5.caption:
A 1961 NSA memo detailing intercepted intelligence that Spanish-speaking pilots were undergoing flight training in Soviet-aligned Czechoslovakia.
    
    
      NSA

6.caption:
Left, Richard Goodwin, an adviser to the president
at the State Department, joined Lansdale in the fateful closed door meeting with Moody at Fort Meade. Right, Col. Edward Lansdale, an assistant secretary of defense,
requested that Moody compile her intercepted Cuban intelligence into a classified report in fall 1961.
    
    
      Bettmann / Getty Images; AP / Shutterstock

7.caption:
Louis Tordella, deputy director of the NSA, was conflicted about circulating Moody’s report about Cuba’s military buildup; in early 1962, he relented.
    
    
      NSA

8.caption:
The coffin of U.S. Air Force Maj. Rudolph Anderson Jr., a
U-2 pilot, is loaded onto a Swiss airplane in Havana. He was shot down during a reconnaissance flight on October 27, 1962.
    
    
      Prensa / Latina via AP Images

3687639657.resolved_title: Was King Arthur a Real Person?
3687639657.excerpt: A cold, wind-driven rain soaks through my parka as I walk across a narrow foot-bridge that links the Cornwall mainland in southwest England to a rocky promontory overlooking the Bristol Channel.

1.caption: Guilbert Gates

2.credit: Art Images / Heritage Images / Getty Images
2.caption:
Arthur appeared in a ninth-century text by Nennius.
    
    
      Art Images / Heritage Images / Getty Images

3.caption:
A labyrinth carving in a woodland known as Rocky Valley. Speculation about its origin ranges from the Early Bronze Age to the 1800s. 
    
    
      Jooney Woodward

4.caption:
In North Cornwall, many a landmark has inspired mystery and magical tales. This prehistoric grouping of stones is known as the Hurlers.
    
    
      Jooney Woodward

5.caption:
Visitors with a would-be Knight of the Round Table outside King Arthur’s Great Halls, devoted to “the symbolism and ideals of the Arthurian tradition.”
    
    
      Jooney Woodward

6.caption:
Thanks to Arthur and his cohorts, the coastal village of Tintagel is a tourist haven. This establishment is the Merlin’s Cave Museum and Shop.
    
    
      Jooney Woodward

7.caption:
The magical sword Excalibur first appeared in Geoffrey of Monmouth’s account under the name Caliburn—derived from a mythical Irish sword called Caladbolg.
    
    
      Jooney Woodward

3220748376.excerpt: After 14 summers excavating in Yellowstone National Park, Doug MacDonald has a simple rule of thumb. “Pretty much anywhere you’d want to pitch a tent, there are artifacts,” he says, holding up a 3,000-year-old obsidian projectile point that his team has just dug out of the ground.

1.caption:
Hunted nearly to extinction by white hunters, bison numbered only about two dozen inside Yellowstone in 1902. Today the herd consists of about 4,800.
    
    
      Andrew Geiger

2.caption: Left: For more than 11,000 years, Obsidian Cliff served as an invaluable source of volcanic glass, which Native Americans fashioned into razor-sharp arrowheads and spear tips. Right: Last summer, archaeologist Doug MacDonald

3.caption:
The caldera is a vast depression formed by the eruption of volcanic magma.
    
    
      5W Infographics

4.credit: Original archival-image photographer: William Henry Jackson
4.caption:
A portable shelter constructed by Shoshone people epitomizes the resourcefulness of hunter-gatherers.
    
    
      Original archival-image photographer: William Henry Jackson

5.caption:
In the region of Yellowstone Lake, migrating Native Americans hunted bison, deer, elk, bear and rabbit, and foraged for foodstuffs including bitterroot and pine nuts. 

    
    
      Andrew Geiger

6.caption:
Left: A 10,000-year-old hunting spear tip made of obsidian. It was produced by knapping, using hard rocks and antlers to break off flakes. Right: For 1,000 years, up until European American contact at Yellowstone, the Shoshone hand-shaped soapstone bowls for cooking and storage. 
    
    
      Andrew Geiger

7.caption:
The majestic 308-foot Lower Falls of the Yellowstone River, as seen from Artist Point. 
    
    
      Andrew Geiger

8.caption:
With the first organized expedition to Yellowstone in 1869, surveyor David Folsom marveled at “springs filled with mud resembling thick paint, pure white to yellow, pink, red and violet.”
    
    
      Andrew Geiger

9.caption:
The grasslands of Lamar Valley, where archaeologists studying former Native American camps have found evidence of butchered bison.  
    
    
      Andrew Geiger

10.caption:
MacDonald's coworkers include Monte White, who is excavating while Scott Dersam and Bradan Tobin sift soil through screens to recover artifacts.

    
    
      Andrew Geiger

11.caption:
Left: Archaeologists at the dig consult the Munsell color chart, a reference that standardizes names applied to sediment-layer colors. Soil stratification is used in dating finds. Right: National Park archaeologist Beth Horton tells visitors that Yellowstone’s “roads and trails here were Native American trails thousands of years ago.”

    
    
      Andrew Geiger

12.caption:
To Native Americans, says Montana State University's Shane Doyle, Yellowstone is “spectacularly diverse, with many climates and cultural zones centered in one place.”
    
    
      Rachel Leathe

13.caption:
A tree swallow soars over Yellowstone Lake. Three hundred bird species have been recorded in the park, including 11 types of owls.
    
    
      Andrew Geiger

14.caption:
Sheepeater Cliff, on the Gardner River, some 6,800 feet above sea level. The Sheepeaters, who were Shoshone, relied on hunting 
bighorns.   
    
    
      Andrew Geiger

15.caption:
MacDonald and colleagues recently unearthed a spear tip, left, and partially worked obsidian fragment, right, roughly 3,000 years old.
    
    
      Andrew Geiger

16.caption:
Left: At the edge of Yellowstone Lake, a white chert flake speaks to the Native presence. Finds there have been scientifically dated to about 1,000 years ago. Right: An obsidian arrow point, left, and a flat chert cutting tool, right, found by archaeologists. The knife would have been used to butcher bison, elk and deer.  
    
    
      Andrew Geiger

17.caption:
Springs at Black Sand Basin, where the water in places is boiling hot and the distinctively colored granules are obsidian. 
    
    
      Andrew Geiger

3767108722.resolved_title: The True Story of Lawrence of Arabia
3767108722.excerpt: Sipping tea and chain-smoking L&M cigarettes in his reception tent in Mudowarra, Sheik Khaled Suleiman al-Atoun waves a hand to the outside, in a generally northern direction. “Lawrence came here, you know?” he says. “Several times. The biggest time was in January of 1918.

1.caption: In desert war, Lawrence advised, get to know “clans and tribes, friends and enemies, wells, hills and roads”

2.caption:
Sheik al-Atoun recalls family tales of Lawrence’s exploits. “He was an expert in demolitions,” al-Atoun says, “and taught my grandfather how it was done.” 
                        Ivor Prickett

3.caption: Capturing Aqaba was Lawrence’s great triumph: “The enemy,” he wrote, “had never imagined attack from the interior”

4.credit: Private Collection / Peter Newark Military Pictures / Bridgeman Images
4.caption: Lawrence

5.caption: After Lawrence’s crash 200 yards from his cottage

6.caption:
A swimmer finds relief from the stifling Arabian heat in the Red Sea in the coastal city of Aqaba, Jordan.  
                        Ivor Prickett

7.caption:
The only seaport of Jordan, Aqaba, on the northeastern tip of the Red Sea, is known today for its beaches and commercial activities.  
                        Ivor Prickett

8.caption:
A shopper examines produce at a market in Aqaba. Lawrence’s crucial battle for Aqaba occurred 40 miles north of the city.
                        Ivor Prickett

9.caption:
Tourists snap photos of  “Lawrence’s camp,” in Wadi Rum, which the British officer passed through during World War I.
                        Ivor Prickett/Panos Pictures

10.caption:
A Bedouin man herds tourist camels across the desert through Wadi Rum, site of the Arab Revolt of 1917-18.
                        Ivor Prickett/Panos Pictures

11.caption:
Storm clouds roll into the Dead Sea valley near the city of Wadi Musa. 
                        Ivor Prickett/Panos Pictures

12.caption:
As a boy, Abu Enad Daraoush  and his friends found remains of Turkish forces at Aba el Lissan—“Bones everywhere,” he recalls, “skulls and ribs and spines.”  
                        Ivor Prickett

13.caption:
Storm clouds roll into the Dead Sea valley near the city of Wadi Musa. 
                        Ivor Prickett/Panos Pictures

14.caption:
Once the site of bloodshed, Aba el Lissan, Jordan, saw T.E .Lawrence and his rebel fighters slaughter hundreds of Turkish soldiers in 1917.
                        Ivor Prickett

15.caption:
Writer Scott Anderson explores the crumbling ruins of southern Jordan’s Turkish forts. 
                        Ivor Prickett/Panos Pictures

16.caption:
Ottoman forts and outposts have fallen to ruin in southern Jordan near the route of the old Hejaz Railway.
                        Ivor Prickett/Panos Pictures

17.caption:
A window in what was once a Turkish fort overlooks a desolate desert landscape near the Hejaz Railway. 
                        Ivor Prickett/Panos Pictures

19.caption:
Turkish trenches, remembrances of the war, scar the landscape in Jordan. 
                        Ivor Prickett/Panos Pictures

20.caption:
A life catalogued in pictures: T.E. Lawrence’s career is captured in photographs on display in Clouds Hill. 
                        Alex Masi

21.caption:
“There is no other man I know who could have achieved what Lawrence did.” Echoing Gen. Edmund Allenby’s sentiments, pictures pay homage to the life of “Lawrence of Arabia” at Clouds Hill.
                        Alex Masi

22.caption:
Before his death, Lawrence retreated to Clouds Hill, a simple cottage in the foothills of southwest England, now open to the public.
                        Alex Masi

23.caption:
Clouds Hill holds many artifacts from Lawrence’s life, including a gramophone and a painting that once belonged to him. 
                        Alex Masi

3282278093.excerpt: At a steady trot, wolves can go 20 miles without breaking stride and cover 50 miles in a day. Their long thin legs move with the inevitability of bicycle wheels, with the rear foot landing in the exact spot just vacated by the front foot and the rest of the wolf flowing along.

1.caption:
New members of the Lassen pack, 2-month-old pups frolic with year-old siblings. In 2020, the pack’s founding female bore another litter, of five pups, while one of her daughters gave birth to four.
    
    
      Morgan Heim

2.caption:
A wolf’s paw print is similar to that of a dog, though generally larger. Finding one near a livestock carcass doesn’t mean Canis lupus was the killer: It is also a keen scavenger.
    
    
      Morgan Heim

3.caption:
Left, Laudon works in his trailer, which serves as field quarters for him and his canine companion, Sammie. Right, his mini fridge doubles as cold storage for vials of blood collected from briefly captured wolves. Here, samples from an alpha female.
    
    
      Morgan Heim

4.caption:
Trail cameras typically are set in the ground or in trees. Combining camera sightings and data from telemetry collars, Laudon has followed the movements of the Lassen pack across 500 square miles.
    
    
      Morgan Heim

5.caption:
A 14-month-old male pup, known as LAS13M, is likely heading toward other wolves in the meadow. He left the pack last year and has been living in Oregon.
    
    
      Morgan Heim

6.caption:
Left, Deana Clifford, a veterinary epidemiologist, works with Laudon, safe-capturing and examining wolves for signs of disease. Right, she adjusts a GPS-equipped radio collar, detectable on the ground up to 20 miles away.
    
    
      Morgan Heim

7.caption: Map: Guilbert Gates; Map Sources: Oregon Fish and  Wildlife, California Department of Fish and Wildlife

8.caption:
A wolf shares a meadow with a herd in Lassen County. Ranchers say the mere presence of wolves stresses cattle, reducing their weight gain—and, thus, profits.
    
    
      Morgan Heim

9.caption:
Field biologist Kent Laudon wields an antenna and a radio receiver in Lassen County to track collared wolves. He sees a place for them in the wild—and also appreciates ranchers’ concerns.
    
    
      Morgan Heim

10.caption:
Although rancher Wallace Roney had one confirmed wolf kill in his herd so far, he believes that depredations will intensify as the wolf population increases.
    
    
      Morgan Heim

11.caption:
George Edward Knox III, Roney’s grandson, displays a photograph of the remains of a slaughtered calf, from one of his family’s herds, that he says was killed by a wolf.
    
    
      Morgan Heim

12.caption:
Some of Roney’s cattle graze in an enclosure marked by colored flags. The movable fencing, called fladry, deters wolves, but Roney notes it requires upkeep and extra labor.
    
    
      Morgan Heim

13.caption:
Kent Laudon and Sammie sit at the edge of what he calls “Pup Meadow,” hoping to spot wolves at the end of the day.

    
    
      Morgan Heim

14.caption:
The Lassen County pack had expanded from one wolf to 15 in five years. Such growth points both to the success of the species in the Golden State and to continued controversy.
    
    
      Morgan Heim

2.caption: Shirtwaists, tailored blouses of the 1890s and early 1900s,  became especially popular with working-class women because, unlike a full dress, they were easy to clean and offered freedom of movement.

3.caption: The International Ladies Garment Workers Union

4.caption: Triangle had modern well-maintained equipment, including hundreds of belt-driven sewing machines, like this Singer sewing machine from about 1920, mounted on long tables and run from floor-mounted shafts.

5.caption: Cash register from Marshall Field's, 1914. At the turn of the century a shopping revolution swept the nation as consumers flocked to downtown palace department stores, attracted by a wide selection of goods sold at inexpensive prices in luxurious environments.

6.caption: An anti-sweatshop advertisement from the Saturday Evening Post, 1902—an era when factory work often took place in small, dank tenement apartments.

1.caption: Airplanes that never flew and a parade of early automobiles now inhabit the grand exhibit hall of the Arts et Métiers museum, once the home of the medieval Saint-Martin-des-Champs monastery.

2.caption: In its inaugural issue, Smithsonian Journeys quarterly takes you to Paris for an intriguing look at the history and culture of the City of Lights. Stroll the streets and learn the surprising ways that past meets present through food, architecture, the arts, local customs and more.
